comments:
This course is an introduction to probability theory, featuring principles of
statistical methods. Specifically, it focuses on problems of estimation and hypothesis,
testing in biology and related areas.
Many students reported that this course was an “excellent course” and the
material was “interesting and very applicable to both research and daily life.” Students
also noted that the course was “really an introduction to statistics,” not necessarily a pure
biology class. Additionally, students appreciated that there was no textbook used in this
course and that all the information could be articulated through lectures and problem sets.
Students agreed that Professor Plotkin “explains everything clearly and succinctly
in class,” making up for the lack of textbook. They also explained that he is “extremely
eloquent and straightforward” in lecture. Despite being a great lecturer in class, a few
students complained that he could be “unapproachable” one on one. Overall, though,
students believed Professor Plotkin was an “amazing professor” who was “very
knowledgeable in the subject.”
Students for the most part found the exams to be “very fair,” though students were
forced to “memorize definitions” and were not necessarily tested enough on
computational problems. Additionally, some students thought the “homework took too
long to complete,” while others wished there had been more practice problems and study
materials. The workload, though, was not too great and this course was highly
recommended to anyone interested in scientific research.
